title: Apps for Synchronized Photo-Audio Recordings to Support Students

author: Marco Zennaro, ICTP - The Abdus Salam International Centre for Theoretical Physics

segmentation: OK, so good morning.
My talk is going to be kind of more on the technical side and it's about application for synchronized photo, an audio recordings to support students.
As I say I come from from Italy from a place called Trieste which is in the northeastern part of Italy from an institution which is called Abdusalam International Center for Theoretical Physics.
So just one slide, I promise once.
Side about our institution, which gives you some background about why we're doing what we're doing.
So they CTP was funded by a Noble price.
Lower it called abdusalam.
In 64.
Those place interest because at that time trace was on the boundary between eastern and Western Europe and the mission of the center is to growth.
The Advanced Research in physics and mathematics, so it's not a University, it's a Research Center.
And especially we tried to foster research among.
Researchers from developing countries.
So this is our clear mission.
How do we do that?
We do that inviting people to.
TP about 6000 people every year, 60% from developing countries and 40% from developed countries.
So people meet there in workshops and seminars and conferences.

They stay there for one week up to six and six months and they do research together so people meet there and do research together and we have about 50 training activities per year in physics and mathematics.
And as you can see from the picture there, we love blackboards.
So people doing physics and mathematics use blackboards.
They don't use PowerPoint that appoint an, so one issue was how do.
You record a lecture which uses the blackboard and in which you know a small dot on the blackboard means a huge difference.
That was our issue with six or seven years ago.
So we developed a system which is called openajax where it just says for enhance your audience.
And it's a system which records a video of the lecture with the students as as macro set, which is shown in the upper left side, and then we take pictures.
We take pictures every 20 to 30 seconds in an automatic way and that is shown in the lower left side.
And there you see you have a black or white box which you can move with your mouse, and doing that you zoom into the picture and you see you get a much clearer vision.
Of the Blackboard system is completely automatic.
It's open source, you can download it on your Linux machine, set it up in your University, and in fact that has been done by many, many universities around the world, and we have many colleagues.
For example in Latin America, recording lectures in physics using this system.
Anne we.
A website calledhttp.tv where we have about 12,000 lectures in physics and mathematics recorded using using this system.
So what happens now is that people come into the center.
As I said, 6000 people ask us how can I record lectures in my University an usually investments are quite low so they cannot go to the administration and ask for money to set up a recording system.
So how could we help them?
Second question was what happens if I attend a seminar?
In my University and I want to record it so it's kind of a spot recording, not, you know, record the whole course, but just one seminar or one lecture.
Amy, we had been thinking about it and adding to the.
Request the incredible growth of mobile phones.
You know there's this feature was produced by the International Telecommunications Union just few months ago.
You see population 7.1 billion and number of subscriptions.
It's almost 7 billion huge number incredible.
But even more incredible is that 70% of these users come from the southern part of the world.
So it's really big in in the southern part of the world.
What about smartphones?
In the USN in Europe, where about 50% of smartphones in a penetration and in many of these countries, that trend is the same.
So now you can buy in Africa, for example smartphone for as low as $20.00.
So people have smartphones and they do have mobile phones and they're interested in recordings.
So if you some little things, we developed some application to use mobile phones to record lectures using the same idea that we had in HTTP.
So record the slides and audio and synchronize them together.
So the idea is to allow students to record lectures using smartphones or tablets.
The investment is very low.
People already have smart phones, so they don't need to invest any money.
And that of course empower students so they can go back home and look at the recording again.
As we know.
And the three point which was really important for us is well sharing.
So we want students to share their recordings with other students.
So not having kind of a repository or situational repository but going like kind of peer to peer OK.
So we developed two applications one.
It's called a job.
It runs on iOS, so on iPhones and on and on iPods, not if on iPad and the other one is called under injure.
Any trans on unreformed.
They're both open source so you can get the source, modify the code and have your own version.
As an example, this is a.
Jobs so the the iPhone and iPad version when you launch the application, you see the middle picture, so you have a record button.
You have a pause button and you have a stop button.
It's that simple and then you have some settings.
So in the settings what you can change is the fixed interval in which you take the pictures.
That can be 5 to 20 seconds or you can be manual.
So if you attend the lecture where the lecture is showing just few slides.
You want to go with the manual version, so you decide when you want to take the picture.
The interesting thing is that the resulting video is in your iOS album, meaning that you can send it through email or you can share it on YouTube that it's that easy.
It is not processed.
It's a video which you can do whatever you want.
The the Android application is, I would say exactly the same so you can record.
Audio and take pictures again.
You have a fixed interval, 5230 seconds or demano and in this case what is generated is a web page, so it's an HTML5 web page.
You have the slides and you have the audio which are synchronized and that can be zipped and again sent through through email.
Give you an example.
This is just a demo.
We took a couple of weeks ago and that is me talking about the system.
There is an audio of course, which is now muted, but you see it takes picture every I think 20 seconds and it is synchronized with the audio.
And in a few slides you will see a blackboard.
Of course it's.
Simply taking pictures to the blackboard.
OK, what is special about?
System, you may wonder why shouldn't you simply record a video with your iPod or with your Alpha iPhone that's already available in your device?

Is the issue comes with the video size, so this is a graph showing a comparison between the video site when you record the video with the iPod and in the case you're recording with our system with a job.
And the left side is the video size in megabytes, and it's it's longer ethnic and on the right side.
On this story in the X axis you have the video links in minutes.
So just starting from 10 minutes you see if you record 10 minutes with your iPad as a video that's about 1 gig.
So there's no way you can share that information with other colleagues, especially if you're in a low bandwidth environment.
If you record with our system, it's about 20 megabytes, so it's really small.
It's something that you can send with, you know, with an attachment, or you can upload to YouTube very easily and.
If you go up to, you know 40 minutes or 15 minutes.
the iPod video is huge, it's gigabytes, and again, there's no way you can share it with our system.
You're always under 100 mix.

So again, something you can send as an attachment and there's not a big difference if you take pictures every 20 seconds, 5 seconds, or in a manual way, and that's because of the compression that is taking place in the video in the video encoding, so the resulting video is really small.
That's I would say the main point to use our system.
I think that's all just few websites I see TV's where we.

To lower videos a open age, the website where you can download the code and the software for Android phones and for iPhone and PIN Box is a new project we're working on which has to do with certification.
So how can you ensure that people actually watched your video?
OK thanks for your attention.
Thanks, this was interesting and the paper was interesting.
We've been looking at mobile devices as well and there's kind of something interesting about them in the classroom and that they democratize the video that's being done.
So instead of getting the institutional video, you get the video that you shot of it, and so now imagine a classroom that's half filled with people doing this.
There's some interesting things that you might be able to do.
For instance, the people in the front row can see the blackboard a lot better.
The people in the back row can see that the set of blackboards better, so you might be able to use that for zooming.

You also have this photosynth like ability, where let's say there's an experiment, so an intro physics one might be just showing people that a feather and a penny in sealed containers that are vacuums fall at the same speed.
So you could have this students cluster around taking the video of this from different angles and then as you watch it allow the students to move around and see it from different.

Perspectives, I'm wondering if you're taking this in those kinds of directions, the big one being that the mobile app you don't just have the one camera, now you have 100 cameras in the crowd that are potentially looking at it.
Or are you looking at keeping it as an individual repository of the lecture?
Maybe you could just comment on.
Yeah, sure I would say that that you know ways our limitation, meaning that we're in.
I mean, we developed the tool and how people use the tool is up to them.
I would say in a certain way and there is some websites where you can upload video sources.

As you say, taken at the same time there like time stamped by different people and you can sync them all together so you can pass from 1 phone to the other away from one video source to the other and that's what we have been looking at.
But that's potentially really.
I mean powerful, sure.
You said that you also have a certification.
Kind of how how to know if people have seen the video?
What kind of data you collect to know if they actually see it, right, right, right?
OK, the system works as the previous speaker was describing for the arts in away, so we have a tool that generates a random number of random, like a voice.
Pretty say voice numbers, so you have your video and not just we detect there is no one speaking and then at a random time we have someone saying 5.
And then after 10 minutes we have someone saying seven OK and those are random numbers.
You don't know how many of these is more interruptions you have and the numbers of course are random.
So injecting this information in the video takes almost no time.
So we're able to put this numbers in different videos and sending them to different students.
So at the end of the lecture you have to provide the three code in a way or the three numbers that were read.
Over over there you know audio Trace.
And we have been experimenting that in several universities and they seem to work fine.
At least you know people you know.
Watch the video and it's only kind of a certification of attending that video lecture.
OK.
Thank you.
